text:
Has anyone ever coded a trading control to validate that the account has sufficient funds to place the bet?
It seems like the latency involved makes it impossible. `get_account_funds` takes a really long time to return.
Has anyone solved this problem?

get_account_funds

takes a really long time to return.

text: Why would you even get into this position at all if you are keeping track of orders and exposures as part of your code? Personally I try to keep a large lump of funds in Betfair - more than my exposure limit in fact. I just see this as an unecessary API operation (apart from maybe once at progrgam start up).

text: Fair enough. We've all been skinned in the past like this I am sure. Seems we have a different in philosophy though - I would not be allocating an exposure of 100 per market on a new strat if I only have 1K in the bank. Good luck to you though, seems Liam has given you plenty of workarounds

text: indeed! i made the numbers up for simplicity and to demonstrate the need for some way of disabling a strategy based on balance. it wasn't quite like what i described when i experienced it. i had a low exposure per market but had a very unlucky run of a large number of markets, followed by a lucky run which didn't get monetised properly ( although with tiny stakes)

elements.text: indeed! i made the numbers up for simplicity and to demonstrate the need for some way of disabling a strategy based on balance. it wasn't quite like what i described when i experienced it. i had a low exposure per market but had a very unlucky run of a large number of markets, followed by a lucky run which didn't get monetised properly ( although with tiny stakes)

text:
FWIW if I run anything new I manually monitor it by running it locally on my machine for as low stakes as I can get away with verbose console logging enabled and fingers on CRTL and C at the ready. I don't use flumine but have similar exposure limits which I know will prevent me getting a total burnout but things still can go to s*it. I'd never run something totally "new" without being there at the first run.

Maybe I am paranoid but tearning through a bankroll just once in life due to one's own coding errors changes a man.

text:
Hi guys,
I am comparing the orderbook data for virtualised and raw prices for the best available to back. My understanding is that the virtualised should always provide an equal or better price than the raw timeseries. When visualizing the data, I see this is not necessarely true, as seen in the chart below. Am I missing something, or the virtual price (in bluye) can at times be worse than the raw batb[0] (in red)? Thanks

elements.text:
Hi guys,
I am comparing the orderbook data for virtualised and raw prices for the best available to back. My understanding is that the virtualised should always provide an equal or better price than the raw timeseries. When visualizing the data, I see this is not necessarely true, as seen in the chart below. Am I missing something, or the virtual price (in bluye) can at times be worse than the raw batb[0] (in red)? Thanks

text: did you get the virt prices from the stream? If i recall correctly, that stream lags behind raw prices

elements.text: did you get the virt prices from the stream? If i recall correctly, that stream lags behind raw prices

text: I did. We are talking about a difference of more than 40 minutes though. From the documentation, it should lag ~100ms

elements.text: I did. We are talking about a difference of more than 40 minutes though. From the documentation, it should lag ~100ms
